required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Changes in Shoulder Kinematics Following an Internal Rotation Fatigue Protocol in Tennis Players
clinical_study.official_title: Changes in Shoulder Kinematics Following an Internal Rotation Fatigue Protocol in Tennis Players

brief_summary.textblock:
Tennis is a global sport that approximately 10% of people play more than 20 times per year in the USA. A typical tennis match can take 1 to 5 hours, and players averagely hit 100 groundstrokes and 400 serves. Tennis serve can be divided into eight stages. Injuries usually happen in the cocking stage and acceleration stage, where it requires large shoulder range of motion and proper scapular motion, including sufficient scapular upper rotation, external rotation, and posterior tilt to produce a powerful serve. Altered shoulder kinematics is are associated with shoulder injuries in tennis players, including delayed shoulder horizontal adduction, and early external rotation. Due to the long duration and repetition of activity in a match, fatigue may happen and result in decreases in sensory input, passive range of motion, ball speed, and muscle strength. These changes may further lead to altered glenohumeral and scapular kinematics. However, previous studies mainly focused on the effects of fatigue on scapular kinematics in constrain movements and applied different fatigue protocols, which lead to inconsistent results. Tennis serve in the acceleration stage requires high activation of shoulder internal rotators, including pectoralis major, subscapularis, latissimus dorsi and serratus anterior. However, to our knowledge, no study has investigated how fatigue of shoulder internal rotators influences shoulder kinematic as well as scapular kinematics during the cocking and acceleration stages of tennis serve. Therefore, the investigators aim to investigate whether fatigue of internal rotator affects shoulder kinematics in healthy tennis players during cocking and acceleration stage s of tennis serve.
This is a single group, pretest-posttest measurement study. In a fatigue protocol, investigators use an isokinetic dynamometer to induce fatigue of shoulder internal rotators. Outcome measures will be tested before and after the fatigue protocol, including peak torque of shoulder internal rotators, humerothoracic kinematics, scapular kinematics, and superficial electromyography. Peak torque of shoulder internal rotators will be measured with an isokinetic dynamometer. Superficial electromyography will be also used to measure the muscle activation of internal rotators during the fatigue protocol. Humerothoracic kinematics and scapular kinematics during a functional tennis serve will be collected with a motion capture system.

primary_outcome.description: Including anterior/posterior tilt, upward/downward rotation, and internal/external rotation in scapula plan elevation at 30°, 60°, 90°, and 120°, will be calculated and will be described with degree (°).
Including shoulder external/internal rotation, horizontal adduction/abduction in the cocking stage of tennis serving,will be calculated and will be described with degree (°).

secondary_outcome.description: Calculate the percentage torque decrease of pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, and latissimus dorsi, described with percentage (%).

The median frequency calculated from electromyographic data of pectoralis major, anterior deltoid, and latissimus dorsi. The percentage change in median frequency will be calculated and will be described with percentage (%).

arm_group.description: Participants in this group need to perform three times of shoulder elevation and five times of tennis serving before and after a fatigue protocol. The fatigue the participants will receive will be conducted with a dynamometer. Surface electromyography on pectoralis major, anterior deltoid ,and latissimus dorsi will be used to detect muscle activity related to fatigue.

intervention.description: We will use an isokinetic dynamometer to conduct the fatigue protocol. The subject will perform isokinetic shoulder internal rotation until the internal rotation torque decreases 50% of maximum torque.

study_pop.textblock: All of the subjects are healthy during the test to avoid the risk of injury.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Healthy tennis players
1. Age ranges from 20-45 years old
2. Engaging in tennis for at least 1 year
3. Routine training 3 times a week
4. No history of cervical and/or shoulder injury in the past one year, or injury with VAS (visual analog pain scale) lower than 3 and without cervical-shoulder pain 7 days before testing
5. No operation on the shoulder, no shoulder subluxation, labral tear, and rotator cuff tear.
6. Neer's test, empty can test, and Hawkins Kennedy test are negative.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. History of cervical and/or shoulder injury in the past one year, or injury with VAS (visual analog pain scale) bigger than 3 and with cervical-shoulder pain 7 days before testing
2. Operation on the shoulder, history of shoulder subluxation, labral tear, and rotator cuff tear.
3. One of the three test results is positive: Neer's test, empty can test, and Hawkins Kennedy test.
4. Perform upper extremity resist training and tennis training 24 hours before testing.
